title: 108_s1582
content: The Act titled "Valles Caldera Preservation Act of 2004" includes amendments to the Valles Caldera Preservation Act. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act of 2004 includes amendments related to the acquisition of outstanding mineral interests, specifying the process and administration by the Secretary. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act of 2004 allows the Secretary to acquire interests with available funds. If negotiations fail, the Secretary will acquire the interests according to section 3114 of title 40, United States Code. Any difference in compensation estimates will be paid from the source of funds. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act allows the Secretary to acquire interests with available funds, with any difference in compensation estimates to be paid from the permanent judgment appropriation. The Trust will determine obligations and expenditures in accordance with applicable laws. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act specifies the process for incurring, allowing, and paying obligations and expenditures. The amendment allows specific members of the Trust to solicit donations. Additionally, the use of proceeds is clarified in relation to claims. The amendment allows specific members of the Trust to solicit donations and exempts claims, judgments, or settlements from activities on the Baca Ranch or the Preserve after October 27, 1999. Resource management is addressed in Section 4. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act is amended to impose limitations on property disposal by the Trust, including maximum duration and termination conditions. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act is amended to impose limitations on property disposal by the Trust, including exclusions for forage, forest products, and renewable resources. Law enforcement and fire management provisions are also updated. Fire management provisions are updated to include non-reimbursable services for fire preparedness, suppression, and emergency rehabilitation on the Preserve. The plan for services on the Preserve must be consistent with the management program and carried out under a cooperative agreement between the Secretary and the Trust. The Secretary may provide reimbursable presuppression and nonemergency rehabilitation services for the Trust on a basis authorized at other National Forest System units. The Senate passed the document on September 15, 2004, with Emily J. Reynolds as the Secretary.
